steps.label: What is a CV for?
desc: A well written, well produced, appropriate CV/curriculum vitae (BrE) or résumé (NAmE) is vital for getting you to the interview stage for a job. This model is an example of how you might structure your CV if you are an experienced candidate applying for a job. This experienced candidate is seeking a senior management position in his field.
Also look at the covering/cover letter.

steps.label: How is it structured?
desc: Below is the framework that was used to create this CV.

steps.label: Personal information
desc: The labels, 'Name', Address', etc. can be omitted. There is no need to mention your age, gender, nationality, race, religion or marital status. Don't send a photo unless you are asked to.

steps.label: Personal Profile
desc: This section gives an employer an idea of who you are.

steps.label: Skills
desc: Experienced candidates often describe their skills before giving their employment history. You can make a lot of this section and include organizational, communication, IT, social, and any other skills relevant to the post you are applying for, in separate sections.

steps.label: Work history and experience
desc: This is shown in reverse order, beginning with the most recent. Begin each job with the title and responsibilities and follow with your achievements. More information is given about the most recent post.

steps.label: Qualifications
desc: These are shown in reverse order and include only key qualifications.

checkList.text: Collect together all the information you need to include in your CV.
Select information that is relevant to the job you are applying for.
Make sure all the information is accurate.
Use action verbs and adjectives to present yourself positively.
checkList.tellMeMore:
Action verbs

Use action verbs to describe your achievements and make them look more dynamic.

Examples: achieved, administered, advised, analysed, arranged, compiled, conducted, coordinated, created, designed, developed, devised, distributed, evaluated, examined, executed, implemented, increased, instructed, introduced, liaised, managed, mentored, monitored, negotiated, organized, oversaw, prepared, recommended, reduced, represented, researched, solved, supervised, trained

Positive Adjectives

Use positive adjectives to describe yourself.

Examples: active, adaptable, committed, competent, dynamic, effective, efficient, enthusiastic, experienced, flexible, (highly) motivated, organized, professional, proficient, qualified, successful

Show Work history and Qualifications in reverse order, beginning with the most recent.
